facts.text: This is a Reference made by the President of India under Article 143(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: This is a Reference made by the President of India under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: The Gujarat State legislature passed an Act by name Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply and Distribution Act, 2001 which came into force w.e.f. 19th December 2000.

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat State legislature passed an Act by name Gujarat Gas  Regulation of Transmission, Supply and Distribution  Act, 2001  hereinafter being referred to as Gujarat Act , which came into force w.e.f. 19th December. 2000.

facts.text: The object of the Gujarat Act is to provide for regulation of transmission, supply and distribution of gas, in the interests of general public and to promote gas industry in the State, and to establish Gujarat Gas Regulatory Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the enactment is to provide for regulation of transmission, supply and distribution of gas, in the interests of general public and to promote gas industry in the State, and for that purpose, to establish Gujarat Gas Regulatory Authority and for matters companynected therewith and incidental thereto.

facts.text: Gas has been defined in the Gujarat Act under Section 2(h) as matter in gaseous state which predominantly consists of methane.

anchor.surface_text: The term Gas has been defined in the Gujarat Act under Section 2 h  as follows- Gas means a matter in gaseous state which predominantly companysists of methane.

facts.text: The State legislature passed the Gujarat Act by tracing its legislative competence under Entry No. 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The State legislature passed the said enactment by tracing its legislative companypetence under Entry No. 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule of the Constitution.

facts.text: Parliament has passed various enactments under Entry No. 53 of List I dealing with petroleum and petroleum products.

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament has passed various enactments under Entry No. 53 of List I dealing with the matters of petroleum and petroleum products.

facts.text: The Federal Legislature passed Petroleum Act, 1934.

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Legislature passed Petroleum Act, 1934.

facts.text: The Union of India enacted Oil Fields Regulation and Development Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Union of India, inter alia, enacted various legislations, namely, The Oil Fields  Regulation and Development  Act, 1948

facts.text: Oil and Natural Gas Commission increased the price of natural gas supplied by them.

anchor.surface_text: Oil and Natural Gas Commission increased the price of natural gas supplied by them.

facts.text: Association of Natural Gas Consuming Industries of Gujarat and others filed Civil Writ Petition before the High Court of Gujarat challenging the legislative competence of the Union to make laws on gas and gas works.

anchor.surface_text: The Association of Natural Gas Consuming Industries of Gujarat and others filed Civil Writ Petition before the High Court of Gujarat wherein they challenged the legislative companypetence of the Union to make laws on gas and gas works.

facts.text: The following questions were referred to this Court under clause (1) of Article 143: 1. Whether natural gas in whatever physical form including LNG is a Union subject covered by Entry 53 of List I. 2. Whether States have legislative competence on natural gas under Entry 25 List II. 3. Whether Gujarat had competence to enact Gujarat Gas Act 2001.

anchor.surface_text: It is in this background, the following questions were referred to this Court under clause 1 of Article 143 of the Constitution of India Whether natural gas in whatever physical form including Liquefied Natural Gas  LNG  is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative companypetence to enact laws on natural gas.

facts.text: Notices were served on the States and the Union Territories after receipt of the Reference.

anchor.surface_text: After the receipt of the Reference, numberices were served on the States and the Union Territories.

facts.text: Learned Attorney General for India contended that natural gas is a Union subject covered by Entry 53 of List I.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney General companytended that the various definitions in different encactments indicate that petroleum and petroleum product include natural gas and it was urged that natural gas is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of List I.

facts.text: Learned Counsel for the State of Gujarat contended that Entry 25 of List II includes all types of gases including natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Counsel for the State of Gujarat, Shri Ashok Desai companytended that the expression gas used in Entry 25 of List 11 would include all types of gases and, therefore, any legislation related to gas and gas works is perfectly within the legislative companypetence of the State,

facts.text: In Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd v. State of West Bengal, this Court held that the field of entire industry dealing with gas and gas works falls under Entry 25 of List II.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that in Calcutta Gas Company  Proprietary  Ltd v. State of West Bengal and Ors., 1962  Suppl.  3 SCR I, the scope and ambit of Entry 25 of List II had been authoritatively pronounced by this Court and this Court held that the field of entire industry, dealing with gas and gas works would fall under Entry 25 of List II.

facts.text: Natural gas is defined in Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia as a naturally occurring mixture of hydrocarbon and non-hydrocarbon gases found in porous geologic formations beneath the earths surface, often in association with petroleum.

anchor.surface_text: In Kirk-Othomer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology, Third Edition, Vol. 11 page 630, Natural gas is defined as a naturally occurring mixture of hydro-carbon and number-hydrocarbon gases found in the porous geologic formations beneath the earths surface, often in association with petroleum.

facts.text: Various Indian legislations define mineral oils or petroleum to include natural gas, such as Oil Fields Regulation and Development Act 1948, Mines Act 1952, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The Oil Fields  Regulation Development  Act, 1948 3 c Mineral Oils include natural gas and petroleum. Mines Act, 1952 2 jj  minerals means all substances which can be obtained from the earth by mining, digging, drilling, dredging, hydraulicing, quarrying or by any other operation and includes mineral oils  which in turn include natural gas and petroleum

facts.text: Natural gas in whatever physical form including LNG is a Union subject covered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative competence.

anchor.surface_text: Natural gas being a petroleum product, we are of the view that under Entry 53 List I, Union Govt. alone has got legislative companypetence.

facts.text: Entry 25 of List II covers manufactured gas and gas works, not natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that under Entry 25 List II of the Seventh Schedule, the State would be companypetent to pass a legislation only in respect of gas and gas-works and having regard to companylocation of words gas and gas works, this Entry would mean any work or industry relating to manufactured gas

facts.text: The Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply and Distribution Act 2001 is ultra vires to the extent it relates to natural gas or LNG.

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Gas  Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution  Act, 2001, so far as the provisions companytained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas  LNG  are companycerned, is without any legislative companypetence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.

facts.text: The Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.
This is a Reference made by the President of India under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India.

issues.text: Whether natural gas in whatever physical form including Liquefied Natural Gas LNG is a Union subject covered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative competence to enact laws on natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: Whether natural gas in whatever physical form including Liquefied Natural Gas  LNG  is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative companypetence to enact laws on natural gas.

issues.text: Whether States have legislative competence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and Liquefied Natural Gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Whether States have legislative companypetence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and Liquefied Natural Gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

issues.text: whether Natural Gas is a Union subject or State subject and whether the State of Gujarat and the other States have the legislative competence to make laws on the subject of Natural Gas.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the question arose whether Natural Gas is a Union subject or State subject and whether the State of Gujarat and the other States have the legislative companypetence to make laws on the subject of Natural Gas.

arguments.claim: Natural gas is included in definitions of petroleum and petroleum products in various enactments, making it a Union subject under Entry 53 List I.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney General contended that the various definitions in different enactments indicate that petroleum and petroleum product include natural gas and it was urged that natural gas is a Union subject covered by Entry 53 of List I. It was contended that the Union Government passed various legislations in respect of Petroleum and Petroleum Products and Mineral Resources, namely, The Oil Fields Regulation and Development Act, 1948 The Oil Industry Development Act, 1974 Petroleum and Minerals Pipelines Acquisition of Right of User in Land , Act, 1962 and Petroleum Natural Gas Rules, 1959, Industries Development and Regulation Act, 1951, as the Parliament alone is competent to do so under Entry 53, List I of the Seventh Schedule.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court surveys multiple statutes defining petroleum/mineral oils to include natural gas and notes consistent legislative practice.

arguments.claim: There is uniform and consistent legislative practice treating petroleum and minerals as including natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by the Attorney General that various definitions indicate that there is uniform and consistent legislative practice and it is evident that the terms Petroleum and Minerals include natural gas.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: thane production or in situ gasification would be appropriate. Liquid Fuel Emergency Act, 1984  Sec. 3  petroleum means a. any naturally occurring hyd

arguments.court_reasoning: Court cites Gannon Dunkerley on importance of legislative practice in interpreting constitutional words.

arguments.claim: Central Government ensures balanced growth in supply, transmission and distribution of natural gas as a petroleum product under Union domain.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government has undertaken the task of ensuring balanced growth in supply, transmission and distribution of natural gas and natural gas being a petroleum product falls exclusively in the domain of the Central legislation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: as got power to make legislation for regulation and development of oil fields, mineral oil resources petroleum, petroleum products, other liquids and

arguments.court_reasoning: National interest in equitable distribution across states justifies Union control.

arguments.claim: Entry 25 List II deals with manufacture of synthetic gas, manufactured gas for lighting, welding etc., not natural gas or mineral oils.

anchor.surface_text: The natural gas in whatever physical form, including Liquefied Natural Gas LNG is a Union subject covered under Entry 53 of List I and Entry 25 under List II of the Seventh Schedule deals with gas and gas works and it relates to manufacture of synthetic gas. Initially manufactured gas was used for lighting street lamps and such other allied purposes. Certain gases like acetylene, oxygen, carbon-dioxide are locally manufactured and used in industries such as for welding purposes, or in hospitals, or for preparing aerated drinks, etc. and Entry 25 under List II enables the State Government to regulate and control the manufacture and distribution of these gases by the local industry and mineral oil resources or petroleum products would not fall under Entry 25 of List II.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of rivers was described as a right publici juris, i.e. a right of public. So also the people of the entire companyntry has a stake in the natural gas

arguments.court_reasoning: Entry 25 means manufactured gas and gas-works, per dictionary definitions and collocation.

arguments.claim: Gujarat Act trenches upon Union field, ultra vires re transmission, distribution, licensing of natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: It was further contended that the provisions of the Gujarat Act seek to trench upon the field reserved for the Union. It was submitted that the Gujarat Act confers authority upon the State Government to regulate the business of distribution and transmission of gas and the provisions of that Act, ex facie, provide for taking over the mineral oil fields and intermeddle in the activities relating to the drilling for oil, etc. It was also pointed out that some other provisions of the said enactment, inter-alia, deal with the licensing and distribution of gas and these provisions are ultra vires of the legislative competence of the State.

arguments.court_reasoning: Provisions relating to natural gas/LNG lack competence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Counsel for the State of Gujarat, Shri Ashok Desai contended that the expression gas used in Entry 25 of List II would include all types of gases and, therefore, any legislation related to gas and gas works is perfectly within the legislative competence of the State,

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Gas and gas-works' refers to manufactured gas only.

State of West Bengal and Ors., 1962 Suppl. 3 SCR I, the scope and ambit of Entry 25 of List II had been authoritatively pronounced by this Court and this Court held that the field of entire industry, dealing with gas and gas works would fall under Entry 25 of List II.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as involving manufactured gas; natural gas not addressed.

arguments.claim: Entries are legislative heads; give widest amplitude; reconcile conflicts via harmonious construction.

anchor.surface_text: It was further submitted that the entries in the three Lists were only legislative heads or fields of legislation and they demarcated the area over which the appropriate Legislature could operate and the widest amplitude should be given to the language of the entries. It was submitted by the learned Counsel for the State that when there is a conflict between two entries, the Court should reconcile the entries and attempt should be made to harmonise the apparently conflicting entries and the State should not be denuded of its power to legislate on the subject.

arguments.claim: Gas can be extracted without petroleum products.

arguments.court_reasoning: Still part of mineral oil resources regulation under Entry 53.

arguments.claim: Entry 25 unambiguous; not limited to manufactured gases; no adding qualifications.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Senior Counsel appearing for the State of Assam submitted that Entry 25 of List II is clear and unambiguous and it is incorrect to suggest that gas and gas works should be limited only to manufactured gases or to gases other than natural gas.

arguments.claim: Gas including natural gas distinct from petroleum commercially, scientifically, industrially.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that the entries in the legislative lists are to be given widest amplitude and it is constitutionally impermissible to add words of qualification to Entry 25 List II. It was argued that in commercial, scientific and industrial parlance. Gas including Natural Gas and Liquefied Natural Gas LNG is quite distinct from Petroleum or Petroleum Products.

arguments.court_reasoning: Encyclopedias and statutes treat natural gas as associated with petroleum.

arguments.claim: Natural resources like gas vital to state economy; federalism requires state control.

anchor.surface_text: It was also pointed out that in a federal structure like ours, a natural resource like gas is fundamental to the very economic existence and prosperity of a State and consistent with the principles of federalism, the State shall not be denied the opportunity to exploit the natural resources.

arguments.court_reasoning: National interest in equitable sharing outweighs; publici juris like water disputes.

arguments.claim: Reconcile lists restricting general words in Union list to preserve state power (citing Byramji Jeejibhai).

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted, relying on the observation in Sir Byramji Jeejibhai v. Province of Bombay. 1939 3 FLJ HC 25 at 31, that the Courts must, if possible, reconcile conflicting items in the Central and Provincial Lists before falling back to the non obstante clause in Section 100 of the Government of India Act, and in applying that principle the Court may restrict the general words of the Federal list so as not to nullify a particular power contained in the Provincial list.

arguments.claim: Gas activities beneficial to state; equivalent to electricity/water under state power.

anchor.surface_text: Learned senior Counsel Mr. P. Chidambaram appearing for the Common Carriers Company contended that any industrial activities connected to gas and gas works are beneficial to the State and the State must be given power to legislate on the subject. The expression gas mentioned in Entry 25 of List II takes within its ambit natural gas which is to be considered as equivalent to electricity and water.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of rivers was described as a right publici juris, i.e. a right of public. So also the people of the entire companyntry has a stake in the natural gas

arguments.court_reasoning: Not analogous; natural gas is petroleum product unlike electricity.

arguments.claim: Natural gas is energy source like heat for homes/industry, not petroleum product.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that natural gas is defined as a naturally occurring mixture of hydrocarbon and non hydrocarbon gases found in the porous geologic formations beneath earths surface and is used principally as a source of heat in residential, commercial and industrial service because of its clean burning quality, convenience of utilisation, low cost and abundance. In other words, natural gas is widely used as a energy source.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: legislative practice of the State which has companyferred the power. In Walace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City and Bombay

arguments.court_reasoning: Use does not determine classification; definitions include it.

arguments.claim: Natural gas categories (wet, lean, dry, sour, sweet) not associated with petroleum.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that natural gas is classified in several broad categories such as 1 wet gas which contains condensable hydrocarbons such as propane, butane and pentane 2 lean gas denotes an absence of condensable hydrocarbons 3 dry gas whose water content has been reduced by dehydration process 4 sour gas contains hydrogen sulfide and other sulfur compounds and 5 sweet gas denotes an absence of hydrogen sulfide and other sulfur compounds. It was submitted that these natural gases are not associated with any petroleum products.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court cites same encyclopedia classifying natural gas, notes association with petroleum.

arguments.claim: Natural gas is a petroleum product per encyclopedias and statutes; associated with petroleum.

anchor.surface_text: In Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology, Third Edition, Vol. 11 page 630, Natural gas is defined as a naturally occurring mixture of hydro-carbon and non-hydrocarbon gases found in the porous geologic formations beneath the earths surface, often in association with petroleum.

arguments.claim: Legislative practice treats natural gas as part of petroleum/mineral oils (lists statutes).

anchor.surface_text: The Oil Fields Regulation Development Act, 1948 3 c Mineral Oils include natural gas and petroleum. Mines Act, 1952 2 jj minerals means all substances which can be obtained from the earth by mining, digging, drilling, dredging, hydraulicing, quarrying or by any other operation and includes mineral oils which in turn include natural gas and petroleum

arguments.claim: Legislative practice important in interpreting constitutional entries (Gannon Dunkerley).

anchor.surface_text: In the State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co., 1959 SCR 379, it was observed that it is important to consider the legislative practice in interpreting the various words used in the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Natural gas under Entry 53 as petroleum product; Union exclusive competence.

anchor.surface_text: Natural gas being a petroleum product, we are of the view that under Entry 53 List I, Union Govt. alone has got legislative competence.

arguments.claim: Entry 25 List II covers only manufactured gas and gas-works.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that under Entry 25 List II of the Seventh Schedule, the State would be competent to pass a legislation only in respect of gas and gas-works and having regard to collocation of words gas and gas works, this Entry would mean any work or industry relating to manufactured gas

arguments.claim: Gujarat Act ultra vires to extent relating to natural gas/LNG.

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution Act, 2001, so far as the provisions contained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas LNG are concerned, is without any legislative competence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Harmonious construction requires reconciling entries; pith and substance for incidental overlap.

anchor.surface_text: In case of apparent conflict, it is the duty of the court to iron out the crease and avoid conflict by reconciling the conflict. If any entry overlaps or is in apparent conflict with another entry, every attempt shall be made to harmonise the same.

arguments.claim: National equitable distribution of natural gas requires Union regulation.

anchor.surface_text: For free and smooth flow of trade, commerce and industry throughout the length and breadth of the country, natural gas and other petroleum products play a vital role... If one State alone is allowed to extract and use natural gas, then other States will be deprived of its equitable share.

holdings.text: Natural Gas including Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) is a Union subject covered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative competence to enact laws on natural gas.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definitions in multiple Union laws include natural gas as petroleum or mineral oil; consistent legislative practice; national interest in equitable distribution; harmonious construction with Entry 25.

holdings.text: The States have no legislative competence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and liquefied natural gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 25 covers only manufactured gas and gas-works, per collocation, dictionary meanings, and distinction from natural gas; Calcutta Gas Co. distinguished as not addressing natural gas.

holdings.text: The Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply and Distribution Act, 2001, so far as the provisions contained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas (LNG) are concerned, is without any legislative competence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Act regulates natural gas transmission/supply/distribution, encroaching on Union field under Entry 53; pith and substance is natural gas regulation beyond state competence.

holdings.text: Natural gas being a petroleum product, under Entry 53 List I, Union Govt. alone has got legislative competence.

anchor.surface_text: Natural gas being a petroleum product, we are of the view that under Entry 53 List I, Union Govt. alone has got legislative competence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Encyclopedic and statutory inclusions of natural gas in petroleum/mineral oils; legislative history.

holdings.text: Under Entry 25 List II of the Seventh Schedule, the State would be competent to pass a legislation only in respect of gas and gas-works ... this Entry would mean any work or industry relating to manufactured gas.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that under Entry 25 List II of the Seventh Schedule, the State would be competent to pass a legislation only in respect of gas and gas-works and having regard to collocation of words gas and gas works, this Entry would mean any work or industry relating to manufactured gas

holdings.reasoning_summary: Collocation 'gas and gas-works' indicates manufactured gas; dictionary definitions; not extending to natural gas.

precedents.citation: Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd v. State of West Bengal and Ors., 1962 Suppl. 3 SCR I

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that in Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd v. State of West Bengal and Ors., 1962 Suppl. 3 SCR I, the scope and ambit of Entry 25 of List II had been authoritatively pronounced by this Court and this Court held that the field of entire industry, dealing with gas and gas works would fall under Entry 25 of List II.

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Gas Company (Proprietary) Ltd. v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: scope and ambit of Entry 25 of List II; entire industry dealing with gas and gas works falls under Entry 25 of List II

precedents.citation: Sir Byramji Jeejibhai v. Province of Bombay. 1939 3 FLJ HC 25 at 31

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted, relying on the observation in Sir Byramji Jeejibhai v. Province of Bombay. 1939 3 FLJ HC 25 at 31, that the Courts must, if possible, reconcile conflicting items in the Central and Provincial Lists before falling back to the non obstante clause in Section 100 of the Government of India Act,

precedents.case_name: Sir Byramji Jeejibhai v. Province of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Courts must reconcile conflicting items in the Central and Provincial Lists

precedents.citation: In re The Central Provinces and Berar Act No. XIV of 1938 1939 ELR 18 at page 42-44

anchor.surface_text: Sir Maurice Gwyer, C.J., in In re The Central Provinces and Berar Act No. XIV of 1938 1939 ELR 18 at page 42-44 observed A grant of the power in general terms, standing by itself, would no doubt be construed in the wider sense,

precedents.case_name: In re The Central Provinces and Berar Act No. XIV of 1938
precedents.cited_proposition: reconciling Entry 45 of List I and Entry 18 of List II; endeavour to solve conflict by context and schemes of the Act
precedents.cited_holding: A grant of the power in general terms... reconciliation attempted between two apparently conflicting jurisdictions

precedents.citation: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee and Ors. v. Bank of Commerce Limited, Khulna, 1947 74 IA 23

anchor.surface_text: In Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee and Ors. v. Bank of Commerce Limited, Khulna, 1947 74 IA 23, which was an appeal from the Federal Court of India, the question arose regarding the validity of the provisions of Bengal Money Lenders Act, 1940.

precedents.case_name: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee v. Bank of Commerce Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: pith and substance doctrine; legislatures bound to overlap
precedents.cited_holding: It is not possible to make so clean a cut between the powers of the various legislatures they are bound to overlap from time to time.

precedents.citation: Subramanyan Chettiar v. Muttitswami Goundar, 1940 FCR 188

anchor.surface_text: The following observations of Sir Maurice Gwyer, C.J. in Subramanyan Chettiar v. Muttitswami Goundar, 1940 FCR 188 were quoted with approval It must inevitably happen from time to time that legislation,

precedents.cited_proposition: pith and substance to determine true nature of legislation
precedents.cited_holding: legislation purporting to deal with a subject in one list touches another; examine pith and substance

precedents.citation: Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Limited supra

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the State of Gujarat submitted that Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule gives power to the State Legislature to make legislation on any subject relating to gas and gas-works and that this was considered by this Court in Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Limited supra

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Gas Company (Proprietary) Ltd. v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: State Legislature has powers under Entry 25 List II regarding gas and gas-works; Oriental Gas Company Act valid
precedents.cited_holding: Entry 24 and 25 overlap; harmonious construction; Entry 25 covers gas industry

precedents.citation: Borys vs. Canadian Pacific Railway Co. and Anr., 1953 1 All ER 451

anchor.surface_text: Learned Senior Counsel, Dr. A.M. Singhvi, appearing for the State of Assam, placed reliance on the decision of the Privy Council in Borys vs. Canadian Pacific Railway Co. and Anr., 1953 1 All ER 451 and contended that gas and petroleum are two distinct commodities.

precedents.case_name: Borys v. Canadian Pacific Railway Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: gas and petroleum are distinct commodities

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co., 1959 SCR 379

anchor.surface_text: In the State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co., 1959 SCR 379, it was observed that it is important to consider the legislative practice in interpreting the various words used in the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: weight to legislative practice in interpreting Constitution words
precedents.cited_holding: have regard to what is ordinarily treated as embraced within that topic in legislative practice

anchor.surface_text: in Croft v. Dumphy, 1933 AC 156, the question was as to the validity of certain provisions in a Canadian statute providing for the search of vessels beyond territorial waters.

precedents.cited_proposition: legislative practice determines scope of power

precedents.citation: Walace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City and Bombay Suburban District

anchor.surface_text: In Walace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City and Bombay Suburban District, Lord Uthwatt observed Where Parliament has conferred a power to legislate on a particular topic it is permissible and important

precedents.case_name: Wallace Brothers & Co. Ltd. v. CIT
precedents.cited_proposition: regard to legislative practice of UK for scope of power

precedents.citation: In Re Cauvery Water Dispute Tribunal, 1993 Supp.l SCC 96

anchor.surface_text: In Re Cauvery Water Dispute Tribunal, 1993 Supp.l SCC 96, the right to flowing water of rivers was described as a right publici juris, i.e. a right of public.

precedents.case_name: In re Cauvery Water Disputes Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: right to flowing water is publici juris

anchor.surface_text: ORDER In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ Petition and Civil Appeals dismissed; Reference answered holding natural gas (including LNG) is Union subject under Entry 53 List I with exclusive Union legislative competence; States lack competence under Entry 25 List II; Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply and Distribution Act, 2001 ultra vires to extent relating to natural gas/LNG.

anchor.surface_text: ORDER In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.
Natural gas being a petroleum product, we are of the view that under Entry 53 List I, Union Govt. alone has got legislative competence.
ORDER In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.

We are of the view that under Entry 25 List II of the Seventh Schedule, the State would be competent to pass a legislation only in respect of gas and gas-works and having regard to collocation of words gas and gas works, this Entry would mean any work or industry relating to manufactured gas
ORDER In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.
